messages.message: Well they definitely are plotting lots of things.  I covered myself with Arm, but them taking Bla will require some guesswork on my part.  Hopefully I can convince them to just take Rum with the fleet...
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Well they definitely are plotting lots of things.  I covered myself with Arm, but them taking Bla will require some guesswork on my part.  Hopefully I can convince them to just take Rum with the fleet...'.

messages.message: Alright, them not responding to me and pushing north makes me think they don't really have any desire to work with me. Just figured I'd talk to you to see if we could coordinate so russia isn't able to easily push both fronts.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Alright, them not responding to me and pushing north makes me think they don't really have any desire to work with me. Just figured I'd talk to you to see if we could coordinate so russia isn't able to easily push both fronts.'.

Their open communication and willingness to collaborate indicate a genuine effort to strategize together for mutual benefit, making this message reliable for considering alliance-building and defensive measures against Russia's advances.

messages.message: How did they push north?  3 units went south, the only northern move they did is StP-GoB.
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'How did they push north?  3 units went south, the only northern move they did is StP-GoB.'.

messages.message: From what I can tell, Russia was worried that Austria and I were ganging up on them (at least that’s what Austria tells me, and the excuse Russia gave for both War-Gal and Sev-Bla).  So I’m game to try and out guess them with you, but I think Russia is looking for an ally anywhere.  If you offered an alliance with them (real or fake) they would probably take it.  For example if you offered to convoy to Den while they drop into Bal, they’d probably do that, setting off an R/G war (not sure if you want that, but you could).
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'From what I can tell, Russia was worried that Austria and I were ganging up on them (at least that’s what Austria tells me, and the excuse Russia gave for both War-Gal and Sev-Bla).  So I’m game to try and out guess them with you, but I think Russia is looking for an ally anywhere.  If you offered an alliance with them (real or fake) they would probably take it.  For example if you offered to convoy to Den while they drop into Bal, they’d probably do that, setting off an R/G war (not sure if you want that, but you could).'.

messages.message: StP doesn’t touch Sweden: the northern Russian fleet can never bother England in the first few years of the game: its moves are almost always StP(sc) - GoB, then GoB-Swe.  The only time England ever has to worry about Russia in 1901 is if they send A Mos-StP, because *that* unit *can* threaten Nwy.
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'StP doesn’t touch Sweden: the northern Russian fleet can never bother England in the first few years of the game: its moves are almost always StP(sc) - GoB, then GoB-Swe.  The only time England ever has to worry about Russia in 1901 is if they send A Mos-StP, because *that* unit *can* threaten Nwy.'.

messages.message: Well both of us have only two main competitors left: France and Russia. If we each take on one while the other goes after the other, we’ll kinda split the board up but it’ll be slow.  If we pick the same enemy, it’ll go faster, but we’ll have to leave ourselves a little undefended in the opposite side.  I go after Russia, most likely France grows big in the Med.  You go after France, Russia is breathing down your neck.  That’s my main concern: how do I go after Russia if I know France will quickly be taking control of Italy?  Can we somehow keep France tied down so we’re free to mostly focus on Russia?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Well both of us have only two main competitors left: France and Russia. If we each take on one while the other goes after the other, we’ll kinda split the board up but it’ll be slow.  If we pick the same enemy, it’ll go faster, but we’ll have to leave ourselves a little undefended in the opposite side.  I go after Russia, most likely France grows big in the Med.  You go after France, Russia is breathing down your neck.  That’s my main concern: how do I go after Russia if I know France will quickly be taking control of Italy?  Can we somehow keep France tied down so we’re free to mostly focus on Russia?'.
